awd_titl_txt: Decomposition Framework for Non-convex Nonsmooth Optimization with Applications in Data Analytics
awd_abstract_narration:
Rapid advances in sensor, communication and storage technologies have led to the availability of data on an unprecedented scale.  Depending on the source, these data may represent measurements, images, texts, time-series and a variety of other formats.  Significant challenges remain in translating the increasing amount of data to useful and actionable information. The objective of this project is to address this information dilemma through the lens of modern large-scale optimization.  This project supports research on methods to effectively process large-scale, unstructured, complex data so as to be usable in applications such as bioinformatics, smart energy systems, manufacturing, and healthcare.  The project will also engage graduate students in the research activities and will support outreach to undergraduate STEM students through an existing program at the PI's university.
 
This project will focus on the construction of a general optimization and computational framework that enables a number of promising but challenging large-scale data-intensive applications.  The research comprises two major thrusts.  The first will build and analyze a novel optimization-based primal-dual decomposition framework that transforms a large, tightly coupled, non-convex problem into a sequence of independent subproblems solvable by parallel machines.  The second applies the decomposition framework to a number of important emerging data-intensive applications, including high-dimensional clustering, topic modeling, and robust high-dimensional regression.  Fundamental questions, such as optimality, convergence rates, and scalability in high dimension will be investigated.  The project will test the developed methods using data from two important energy applications: smart energy meters and real-time residential photovoltaic inverters.

por.por_cntn:
Project Overview:

Our primary objective in this project was to address the pervasive information dilemma through the lens of large-scale optimization. We aimed to create an optimization-oriented framework that serves as a bedrock for large-scale signal and information processing applications. The project has yielded results that advance both theory and practice in non-convex optimization and its applicability in several domains.

 

Accomplishments:

Developing Advanced Optimization Methods: We have developed a number of first-order optimization methods that can deal with a large class of non-convex problems without stringent assumptions, such as those without global Lipschitz constant. This is particularly useful for polynomial optimization and neural network training. Further, we have developed and analyzed a certain penalty dual decomposition framework, which can deal with algorithms with generic, even non-convex constraints. Finally, we have extensively worked on developing algorithms for decentralized optimization, in which multiple agents coordinating together to optimize a global objective. All these methods are easy to implement in practice since they mostly only utilize first-order information; Meanwhile, they all process strong theoretical properties, such as global convergence and convergence rate guarantees.

 

Linking Non-Convex Optimization with Applications:  We have developed algorithms for a number of machine learning applications, in particular the class of adversarial machine learning problems, where the goal is to attack (in the perspective of the attacker), or robustify (in the perspective of the system developer) popular deep learning based systems. One interesting development here is that we have adapted the first-order algorithms developed in early stages of this project, to the zeroth-order setting, where only loss function evaluations are required to perform updates. This algorithm turns out to be very useful in the black-box attack setting, where the adversary does not have access to the machine learning system under attack, but it is still able to significantly reduce the system performance.

 

Further, we have customized the algorithms developed for generic problems, to wide application areas beyond data analytics and machine learning, such as power systems, healthcare systems, multi-agent systems, signal processing and wireless communication. It is worth mentioning that, we have ventured to the uncharted territory (at the time) of using deep learning algorithms to “learn” the behavior large-scale first-order algorithms, and then use the learned network to optimize a wireless communication system. The resulting approach, known as “learning to optimize”, has gained significant popularity in the wireless communication / signal processing community.

 

 

Recognition and Awards:

Our paper titled “Learning to Optimize: Training Deep Neural Networks for Interference Management” was honored with the IEEE Signal Processing Society (SPS) Best Paper Award in 2022. In recognition of his contributions to optimization and machine learning, the PI has received the Pierre-Simon Laplace Early Career Technical Achievement Award by the IEEE SPS.

 

Conclusion:

The success of this project is evident in its contribution to the theory and application of large-scale optimization. The methodologies, algorithms, and insights generated during this endeavor will serve as a foundation for subsequent research. Furthermore, the accolades received are a testament to the value and impact of the project on the broader scientific community.
